title: 105_hr3642
content:
The Act may be cited as the "Judicial District of the Virgin Islands Act of 1998" and establishes the District Court of the Virgin Islands as an Article III court. The "Judicial District of the Virgin Islands Act of 1998" establishes the District Court of the Virgin Islands as an Article III court with two divisions: the Saint Croix Division and the Saint Thomas and Saint John Division. Court sessions are held at Christiansted for the Saint Croix Division and at Charlotte-Amalie for the Saint Thomas and Saint John Division. Chapter 5 of title 28, United States Code, is amended by inserting a new section after section 126. Chapter 5 of title 28, United States Code, is amended by inserting a new section after section 126, adding the item relating to the Virgin Islands in the table of judges. The Revised Organic Act of the Virgin Islands repeals sections 25, 26, and 27, and amends section 3 by inserting "article III;" and specifying that offenses under local laws will continue to be prosecuted by information. The Revised Organic Act of the Virgin Islands specifies that offenses under local laws will continue to be prosecuted by information, except those required by local law to be prosecuted by indictment by grand jury. The jurisdiction of local courts is also amended. The jurisdiction of local courts in the Virgin Islands is specified in SEC. 21. The judicial power of the Virgin Islands is vested in local trial or appellate courts with jurisdiction over causes of action not under exclusive jurisdiction of US courts. Rules for practice, procedure, qualifications of judges, and court operations are governed by local law or court rules. Section 22 of the Revised Organic Act of the Virgin Islands is amended regarding jurisdiction over criminal matters and income tax. "SEC 22. Jurisdiction over criminal matters and income tax." The United States District Court for the District of the Virgin Islands has exclusive jurisdiction over criminal and civil proceedings related to income tax laws in the Virgin Islands, except for ancillary laws enacted by the Virgin Islands legislature. Any violation of income tax laws that would be a criminal offense under the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 is considered an offense against the government of the Virgin Islands. The United States District Court for the District of the Virgin Islands has exclusive jurisdiction over criminal and civil proceedings related to income tax laws in the Virgin Islands. Violations of income tax laws are considered offenses against the government of the Virgin Islands and may be prosecuted in the United States District Court without the consent of the United States attorney for the Virgin Islands. Relations between United States courts and local courts are governed by the Revised Organic Act of the Virgin Islands. Relations between United States courts and local courts are governed by the Revised Organic Act of the Virgin Islands. The laws of the United States govern the relations between US courts and local courts, including appeals, certiorari, and habeas corpus. The US Court of Appeals for the Third Circuit has jurisdiction to review final decisions of the highest court in the Virgin Islands for the first 15 years after the establishment of the appellate court. The US Court of Appeals for the Third Circuit has jurisdiction to review final decisions of the highest court in the Virgin Islands. The Judicial Council of the Third Circuit must report to Congress every 5 years on whether the appellate court in the Virgin Islands is ready for direct review by the Supreme Court. The Third Circuit can establish rules to implement this section. The Revised Organic Act of the Virgin Islands is amended to replace "District Court of the Virgin Islands" with "United States District Court for the District of the Virgin Islands" and allows for the assignment of additional judges to the court. The Revised Organic Act of the Virgin Islands allows for the assignment of additional judges to the United States District Court for the District of the Virgin Islands. The Revised Organic Act of the Virgin Islands permits the assignment of extra judges to the US District Court for the District of the Virgin Islands by the Chief Judge of the Third Judicial Circuit or the Chief Justice of the United States with consent. After the establishment of the appellate court authorized by the Revised Organic Act of the Virgin Islands, judges described in paragraph (1)(A) cannot be assigned to the district court. All pleadings and proceedings in the US District Court for the District of the Virgin Islands must be conducted in English. Pending cases in the District Court of the Virgin Islands can be pursued to final determination in the United States District Court for the District of the Virgin Islands, the United States Court of Appeals for the Third Circuit, and the United States Supreme Court. Existing officers of the court in the Virgin Islands can continue in their roles until a successor is appointed. SEC. 3. TECHNICAL AND CONFORMING AMENDMENTS. In technical and conforming amendments, retirement and survivors' annuities under title 28, United States Code, are modified for district court judges. The Act modifies service calculations for judges of the District Court of the Virgin Islands and clarifies that existing retirees' rights are unaffected. Additionally, references to the District Court of the Virgin Islands are removed in various sections of title 28, United States Code. The Act amends various sections of title 28, United States Code by removing references to the District Court of the Virgin Islands and replacing them with the District Court of Guam. The Act amends title 18, United States Code by replacing references to the District Court of the Virgin Islands with the District Court of Guam. SEC. 4. ADDITIONAL REFERENCES.

Any mention of the "District Court of the Virgin Islands" in any law provision will now refer to the United States District Court for the District of the Virgin Islands.

SEC. 5. EFFECTIVE DATE.

This Act and its changes will become effective 90 days after the enactment date.
